entry.itemBody: Assume that a central bank has decided to lower interest rates in the economy. To carry out this policy, the central bank will most likely:

answerFeedback.04ab9ee5-2a14-4619-9199-b7edb5d6766b: Incorrect. An increased reserve requirement reduces the money supply (as banks can lend out less) and leads to higher interest rates.
answerFeedback.619d78fd-05b0-40de-a988-328d98c013d8: Correct. In implementing monetary policy, central banks have three primary tools available to them: open market operations (which including purchasing securities), setting the official policy rate, and reserve requirements. When the central bank purchases securities, it increases the reserves held by private sector banks. These increased reserves lead to a reduction in interest rates on money market securities and, ultimately, to a reduction in other interest rates in the economy.
answerFeedback.6faccb4d-e3cc-4f64-aa1f-ddf930c1358e: Incorrect. If the central bank sells securities, reserves fall and interest rates are likely to increase.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-FRA-Roberts-20
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information (in € millions) about a company's current assets and liabilities:

Cash 200
Short-term marketable investments 300
Receivables 1,000
Inventory 1,500
Current liabilities 5,000

The quick ratio is:

answerFeedback.0b1fd344-a888-49b6-9594-30d425d7ae73: Incorrect because it assumed the denominator of the Quick ratio is Current assets instead of Current liabilities. The calculation thus becomes: (Cash + Short-term marketable investments + Receivables) ÷ Current Assets = (200 + 300 + 1,000) ÷ (200 + 300 + 1,000 + 1,500)= 1,500 ÷ 3,000 = 0.50.
answerFeedback.79a3f87c-f464-4108-b190-b7bf238246dc: Correct because the Quick ratio = (Cash + Short-term marketable investments + Receivables) ÷ Current Liabilities. The calculation is (200 + 300 + 1,000) ÷ 5,000 = 1,500 ÷ 5,000 = 0.30.
answerFeedback.acb50fcc-a1d6-4f08-b245-52222475235f: Incorrect because it is the Cash ratio instead of the Quick ratio. The calculation is Cash ratio = (Cash + Short-term marketable investments) ÷ Current Liabilities = (200 + 300) ÷ 5,000 = 500 ÷ 5,000 = 0.10.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2023.06-CorpIssuers-Trent-05
entry.itemBody: Proxy voting is best defined as a means for:

answerFeedback.1ccc83f8-6a16-4418-bc98-9121132d3486: Incorrect because this is but one use of the proxy voting process, and thus not the best description of it. Changes in corporate control via a takeover by shareholders or an acquirer may be pursued in several ways. One mechanism is the proxy contest (or proxy fight). In a proxy contest, a group seeking a controlling position on a company’s board of directors attempts to persuade shareholders to vote for the group.
answerFeedback.357e5a14-cd71-4981-9db7-5520d9cb9cbe: Correct because shareholders unable to attend a meeting in person usually authorize another party to vote on their behalf in a proxy voting process, typically by submitting a ballot electronically or by mail. Proxy voting is the most common form of investor participation in general meetings
answerFeedback.ee1508f0-88ef-41e3-8723-c8c9ef21f454: Incorrect because, while shareholder activists often pressure management to act using tactics such as initiating proxy fights, proposing shareholder resolutions, and publicizing issues of contention, this is but one use of the proxy voting process.

choices.itemBody: A. a would-be acquirer to gain control.
C. shareholders voting without attending a meeting in person.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06937
entry.itemBody: The NZD/EUR (amount of NZD per 1 EUR) spot rate is 1.5453. If the 3-month forward discount is 24 points, the 3-month forward rate is closest to:

answerFeedback.8c5c797b-ba44-4c52-b840-9815af8e4394: Incorrect because it multiplies the spot rate by (1 + the forward discount) rather than adding it; 1.5453 × (1 + 0.0024) ≈ 1.54901.
answerFeedback.e4293e0d-567f-4357-bc52-0ad2f1240188: Incorrect because it adds, rather than subtracts, the forward discount; 1.5453 + 0.0024 = 1.54770.
answerFeedback.e802a9b4-4e2f-4a01-9d69-fd24a3cbe7af: Correct because if the forward rate is less than the spot rate, the points (forward rate minus spot rate) are negative and the base currency is said to be trading at a forward discount. To convert quoted forward points into a forward rate, one would divide the number of points by 10,000 (to scale down to the fourth decimal place, the last decimal place in the spot quote) and then add the result to the spot exchange rate quote. Therefore, scaling down the forward points by dividing by 10,000 gives a forward discount of 24/10,000 = 0.0024. Since it is a discount, subtracting it from the spot rate results in a three-month forward rate of 1.5453 – 0.0024 = 1.54290.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-Quant-Tsependa-06
entry.itemBody:
An analyst calculates the following metrics about a sample of paired observations of a dependent variable Y and an independent variable X:

Variance of X 9
Variance of Y 15
Covariance of Y and X 12

Based on the sample, the slope coefficient of the simple linear regression of Y to X is closest to:

answerFeedback.6ae21caa-4e0e-4dd0-8f4d-72c703e7bea9: Incorrect because it used the variance of Y, and not the variance of X, in the denominator, and calculates the slope = 12 / 1. It is also closest to the inverse of the correct answer, 9/12 = 0.75.
answerFeedback.d41601e0-1219-4370-b701-b8576b1dfc25: Incorrect because it is the sample correlation between X and Y, and not the slope of the linear regression. The sample correlation, r, is the ratio of the covariance to the product of the standard deviations, and thus equals 12 / ((90.5)(150.5)) = 12 / 11.62 = 1.0328 ≈ 1.03.
answerFeedback.e4640528-bf0f-469e-ac64-b2ec3ca96d24: Correct because the slope of a linear regression is the ratio of the covariance between Y and X to the variance of X, thus slope = 12/9 ≈ 1.33.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-03237
entry.itemBody: The third quintile corresponds to the:

answerFeedback.3c161a3b-cc0a-42c8-92d9-8522d0623e62: Incorrect because the third quintile corresponds the 60th percentile. Statisticians use the word quantile (or fractile) as the most general term for a value at or below which a stated fraction of the data lies. While the 40th percentile is the beginning of the range that contains the values in the third quintile, it is not the value at which 60% of observations lie at or below it.
answerFeedback.d095a170-cedc-494d-9572-77d338e12ad5: Incorrect because the third quintile corresponds the 60th percentile. Statisticians use the word quantile (or fractile) as the most general term for a value at or below which a stated fraction of the data lies. While the 50th percentile is the midpoint of the range that contains the values in the third quintile, it is not the value at which 60% of observations lie at or below it.
answerFeedback.fe68159b-d58a-4128-a698-75f29a449d37: Correct because quartiles divide the distribution into quarters, quintiles into fifths, deciles into tenths, and percentiles into hundredths. Given a set of observations, the yth percentile is the value at or below which y% of observations lie. Quintiles divide the distribution based on the 20th, 40th, 60th, and 80th percentile. As such, the third quintile corresponds to the 60th percentile.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-Quant-Tomter-12
entry.itemBody: Goodness of fit measures derived from analysis of variance (ANOVA) data most likely include the:

answerFeedback.2cc2647b-8149-4a01-a2d2-e44f2dc981fc: Incorrect because the regression coefficients, the intercept and slope coefficient, are derived from the initial ordinary least squares regression, not the analysis of variance.
answerFeedback.398823f9-db6a-4556-9c5c-1ff9e913f211: Incorrect because the coefficient of determination is a goodness of fit measure, not the coefficient of variation. The coefficient of variation is a measure of relative dispersion. The coefficient of variation, CV, is the ratio of the standard deviation of a set of observations to their mean value. The se, (the standard error of the estimate), along with the coefficient of determination and the F-statistic, is a measure of the goodness of the fit of the estimated regression line.
answerFeedback.634b42e7-717c-4f88-8ad1-befe05f1c915: Correct because we often represent the sums of squares from a regression model in an analysis of variance (ANOVA) table, which presents the sums of squares, the degrees of freedom, the mean squares, and the F-statistic. The se, (the standard error of the estimate), along with the coefficient of determination and the F-statistic, is a measure of the goodness of the fit of the estimated regression line.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B FRA 01CXM
entry.itemBody: PP&E may be reported above its historical cost on the balance sheet under:

answerFeedback.0feb9113-87ac-4ce4-adac-5ae6a3d2a0db: Correct because the revaluation model may result in increases in the values of long-lived assets to amounts greater than historical costs.
answerFeedback.aa25de09-26ab-4f4c-ab51-d281aaa5afeb: Incorrect because the cost model allows only decreases in the values of long-lived assets compared with historical costs.
answerFeedback.f4bd3589-cdfa-4afc-970d-a2819e76adae: Incorrect because a key difference between the two models is that the cost model allows only decreases in the values of long-lived assets compared with historical costs but the revaluation model may result in increases in the values of long-lived assets to amounts greater than historical costs.

choices.itemBody: C. both the cost model and the revaluation model.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-CorpFin-Georgiou-07
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a company:

Market value of equity $64 million
Cost of equity 14%
Market value of debt $20 million
Before-tax cost of debt 5%
Marginal tax rate 30%

The company's WACC is closest to:

answerFeedback.6d4c5721-c0ce-4246-8450-0db224d2a86a: Incorrect because the cost of debt is adjusted for tax by multiplying the cost of debt with the tax rate instead of multiplying it by (1 – the marginal tax rate). WACC ≠ 0.2381 × 5% × 30% + 0.7619 × 14% = 0.11024 ≈ 11.02%.
answerFeedback.8e6cdca0-3c29-4fe3-b80d-f6ea69dc8bdf:
Correct because WACC = wdrd(1 – t) + wprp + were 

where

wd = the proportion of debt that the company uses when it raises new funds,

rd = the before-tax marginal cost of debt,

t = the company’s marginal tax rate,

wp = the proportion of preferred stock the company uses when it raises new funds,

rp = the marginal cost of preferred stock,

we = the proportion of equity that the company uses when it raises new funds,

re = the marginal cost of equity.

wd = $20m/($20m + $64m) = 0.2381 and we = $64m/($20m + $64m) = 0.7619

WACC = 0.2381 × 5% × (1 – 30%) + 0.7619 × 14% = 11.50%.
answerFeedback.c76b5b75-ad3d-4f78-90cd-d43aa6f905ee: Incorrect because the cost of debt is not adjusted with the marginal tax rate. WACC ≠ 0.2381 × 5% + 0.7619 × 14% = 0.11857 ≈ 11.86%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2023.01-FSAN-Harper-14
entry.itemBody:
An analyst uses the following information to forecast a company's gross profit margin: 

  Current Amount (in $ millions) Forecasted Growth

Sales

 1,200 4%
Cost of sales 300 8%

The analyst's gross margin forecast would be closest to a(n):

answerFeedback.766e74b0-375e-4c78-8f5f-acedfc914d67: Correct because the gross profit for the current year is 900 (=1,200 – 300), therefore the current gross profit margin is 75%.  If sales increase by 4% (to 1,248) and cost of sales increase by 8% (to 324), the forecasted gross profit is 924 (= 1,248 – 324), and the forecasted gross profit margin is 74.04%.  This is a decrease of approximately 1% (= 74.04% – 75%).
answerFeedback.beb269b8-948f-478e-9d52-3fb62bc9eab0: Incorrect because it assumes the starting values have the same base and takes the difference in the growth rates; –4% = sales growth – cost of sales growth = 4% – 8%.
answerFeedback.ee6d71af-04cd-40e4-8997-951a51f2e2fc: Incorrect because it computes the gross profit margin as cost of sales / sales.  Current gross profit margin is 25% (= 300 / 1,200) and the forecasted gross profit margin is 25.96% (= 324 / 1,248) an increase of approximately 1%.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B Quant 02CXG
entry.itemBody: A series of five annual tuition payments of $25,000 each will begin exactly 20 years from today. If the stated annual rate is 4%, the required investment today to fund all five payments is closest to:

answerFeedback.74951d93-c0d2-405b-81fe-8bd71e331f8f: Incorrect because it calculates the present value of an annuity due at t = 20 and then discounts the PV of the projected annuity due by 19 years instead of 20 years. The PV of the 5-year annuity due at t = 20 equals $25,000{[1 – 1/(1 + 0.04)5]/0.04}(1.04) = $25,000{[1 − 0.82193]/0.04}(1.04) = $25,000(4.62990) = $115,747.38. The PV at t = 0 is equal to $115,747.38/(1 + 0.04)19 = $115,747.38/2.10685 = $54,938.62 ≈ $54,939. Calculator solution: in BGN mode; N = 5; I/Y = 4; PMT = 25,000; solve for PV = 115,747.38; then discount for 19 years: FV = 115,747.38; N = 19; I/Y = 4; solve for PV = 54,938.62.
answerFeedback.8f6f23d0-268e-4e0f-b127-2b62f0c48782: Correct because the present value formulas for an ordinary annuity and a lump sum are PV = A[1 – 1/(1 + r)N]/r and PV = FVN/(1 + r)N, respectively. The PV of the 5-year ordinary annuity at t = 19 (1 year before the first payment) equals $25,000[1 – 1/(1 + 0.04)5]/0.04 = $25,000[1 – 0.82193]/0.04 = $25,000(4.45182) = $111,295.56. The PV at t = 0 is equal to $111,295.56/(1 + 0.04)19 = $111,295.56/2.10685 = $52,825.59 ≈ $52,826. Calculator solution: in END mode; N = 5; I/Y = 4; PMT = 25,000; solve for PV = 111,295.56; then discount for 19 years: FV = 111,295.56; N = 19; I/Y = 4; solve for PV = 52,825.59 ≈ 52,826. Alternatively: in BGN mode; N = 5; I/Y = 4; PMT = 25,000; solve for PV = 115,747.38; then discount for 20 years: FV = 115,747.38; N = 20; I/Y = 4; solve for PV = 52,825.59.
answerFeedback.fa986055-fb50-4f8c-a51c-60be3057845b: Incorrect because it discounts the present value of the projected ordinary annuity by 20 years instead of 19 years. The PV of the 5-year ordinary annuity at t = 19 (1 year before the first payment) equals $25,000[1 – 1/(1 + 0.04)5]/0.04 = $25,000[1 – 0.82193]/0.04 = $25,000(4.45182) = $111,295.56. The PV at t = 0 is equal to $111,295.56/(1 + 0.04)20 = $111,295.56/2.19112 = $50,793.84 ≈ $50,794. Calculator solution: in END mode; N = 5; I/Y = 4; PMT = 25,000; solve for PV = 111,295.56; then discount for 20 years: FV = 111,295.56; N = 20; I/Y = 4; solve for PV = 50,793.84.

entry.title: ITEM_20170608262
entry.itemBody: Which of the following companies would most likely be considered to have the lowest financial reporting quality, other things equal?

answerFeedback.2b5adf7d-728c-4a89-8308-294880381a1d: Incorrect. The company’s reports are high quality, but the delay in reporting impairs their usefulness somewhat. The reporting is still better than biased reporting.
answerFeedback.4ebaeaac-97dd-4272-b720-0de349755da9: Incorrect. This is an example of decision-useful information about a result that may not be sustainable. Reporting is not of the highest quality, but is better than biased reporting.
answerFeedback.c104ad97-d76d-4971-a087-15e0993add40: Correct. Combining the results from two segments is an example of biased reporting, which falls in the middle of the quality spectrum. It is difficult to interpret the profitability of each segment when their results are combined.

choices.itemBody: A. A company that reports significant profits due to a favorable exchange rate movement.
B. A company that reports the results from two different segments as a combined entity.
C. A company that provides high quality, decision-useful information under GAAP but delays its reports.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.01-CorpIssuers-Tsependa-09
entry.itemBody: In which of the following business structures do owners share all risk and business liability?

answerFeedback.c4297ef5-a331-4cf6-9703-f186ae6fe20c: Correct because general partnerships have a small number of partners who establish the business by contributing equal amounts of capital. A key feature of general partnerships is that partners share all risk and business liability.
answerFeedback.c731bd4e-2dfa-4384-aabf-4737beb649cc: Incorrect because like a limited partnership, owners in a corporation (and US LLC) have limited liability, and don't share all risk and business liability.
answerFeedback.e25eed1e-c110-427b-a1b8-d115b29df908: Incorrect because a limited partnership must have at least one general partner with unlimited liability who is responsible for the management of the business. Remaining partners, called limited partners, have limited liability, meaning they can lose only up to the amount of their investment in the limited partnership.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-CorpIssuers-Su-13
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information (in $ millions) about three companies:

  Company 1 Company 2 Company 3
Cash 2.5 2.0 1.5
Short-term marketable instruments 4.0 1.0 1.0
Receivables 2.0 2.0 1.0
Inventory 1.0 1.0 3.0
Current liabilities 5.0 2.5 2.0

Based on the quick ratio, which company exhibits the lowest liquidity risk?

answerFeedback.3329b4d6-6d4b-4833-99c6-693d933d3506:
Correct because Company 2 has the highest quick ratio.

Quick ratio = (Cash + Short-term marketable instruments + Receivables) / Current liabilities

The following is calculated in $ millions:

Company 1 quick ratio = (2.5 + 4.0 + 2.0) / 5.0 = 1.70

Company 2 quick ratio = (2.0 + 1.0 + 2.0) / 2.5 = 2.00

Company 3 quick ratio = (1.5 + 1.0 + 1.0) / 2.0 = 1.75
answerFeedback.5bdbf881-41bf-4b9b-aede-88344c487961:
Incorrect because Company 1 has the highest cash ratio but not the highest quick ratio.

Cash ratio = (Cash + Short-term marketable instruments) / Current liabilities

The following is calculated in $ millions:

Company 1 cash ratio = (2.5 + 4.0) / 5.0 = 1.30

Company 2 cash ratio = (2.0 + 1.0) / 2.5 = 1.20

Company 3 cash ratio = (1.5 + 1.0) / 2.0 = 1.25
answerFeedback.92b87d14-3d82-46a1-817c-c5d492876c03:
Incorrect because Company 3 has the highest current ratio but not the highest quick ratio. 

Current ratio = (Cash + Short-term marketable instruments + Receivables + Inventory) / Current liabilities

The following is calculated in $ millions:

Company 1 current ratio = (2.5 + 4.0 + 2.0 + 1.0) / 5.0 = 1.90

Company 2 current ratio = (2.0 + 1.0 + 2.0 + 1.0) / 2.5 = 2.40

Company 3 current ratio = (1.5 + 1.0 + 1.0 + 3.0) / 2.0 = 3.25

entry.title: ITEM_20180516071
entry.itemBody: For a company paying preferred dividends, the components needed to compute basic EPS are net income:

answerFeedback.408bcaab-edfb-4817-9d46-9241a3af113b: Incorrect because basic EPS is not adjusted for additional ordinary shares issued, an adjustment which uses the if-converted method for potentially dilutive securities. This method is applicable when determining diluted EPS.
answerFeedback.e1af4eea-d767-4254-a039-f22452d9a7a9: Correct. Basic EPS is calculated by subtracting preferred dividends from net income and then dividing the result by the weighted average number of shares outstanding.
answerFeedback.f39ce03f-c93f-49f7-8e04-125caf73102e: Incorrect because preferred dividends must be subtracted from net income before dividing by the weighted average number of shares outstanding.

choices.itemBody: A. and the weighted average number of common shares outstanding.
B. preferred dividends, and the weighted average number of common shares outstanding.
C. preferred dividends, additional shares issued if preferred is converted, and the weighted average number of common shares outstanding.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-00156
entry.itemBody: In monopolistically competitive markets, economic profits:

answerFeedback.4827c01e-b7e5-4674-a5fe-78462908e817: Incorrect because in the short run a monopolistically competitive firm is able to earn a positive economic profit. In the short run, the profit-maximizing choice is the level of output at which Marginal Revenue = Marginal Cost
answerFeedback.c8575a2a-4d0f-4f17-b40a-0fba8837a7ea: Correct because in the short run a monopolistically competitive firm is able to earn a positive economic profit. In the short run, the profit-maximizing choice is the level of output at which Marginal Revenue = Marginal Cost.  However, in the long run for the monopolistically competitive firm, economic profit will fall to zero.
answerFeedback.d05e2ade-88ad-4f33-902d-3673d503e8a6: Incorrect because in the long run for the monopolistically competitive firm, economic profit will fall to zero.

choices.itemBody: B. can be earned in the short run only.
C. can be earned in the short run and in the long run.

entry.title: ITEM_20170608251
entry.itemBody:
An analyst is comparing the solvency of a company over the past two years using the information below:
Year 2 ¥ Millions
Total debt 2,300
Total shareholders’ equity 17,000
Total assets 20,000
Net income 375
Interest payments/interest expense 200
Taxes paid 125
Ratios in Year 1
Debt to capital 12.7%
Interest coverage 2.9

The best conclusion the analyst can make about Year 2 is that compared with Year 1, the company’s solvency has:

answerFeedback.c5fc04d2-a889-4d6f-9bea-5488ba93611b: Incorrect because both ratios have improved from Year 1 to Year 2, thus the company is more solvent in Year 2
answerFeedback.d139a527-ff80-494f-99fd-20992fbad81a:
Correct because both ratios have improved from Year 1 to Year 2, thus the company is more solvent in Year 2.

Year 1 Year 2 calculations Year 2
Debt to capital 12.7% 2,300/(2,300 + 17,000) = 11.9% 11.9%
Interest coverage 2.9 (375 + 200 + 125)/200 = 3.5 3.5
answerFeedback.ff039a09-6e4e-4734-adb3-ed0498718dbc: Incorrect because it calculates interest coverage using net income instead of EBIT (1.875), and interprets the change in debt to capital as a deterioration because the value has decreased.

choices.itemBody: A. deteriorated because both ratios have weakened.
C. improved because both ratios have strengthened.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.01-Quant-Zhang-10
entry.itemBody: In hypothesis testing, the critical value is determined by the:

answerFeedback.682078f8-c598-4043-8382-cc078a9681a0: Incorrect because the p-value is the area in the probability distribution outside the calculated test statistic.
answerFeedback.90cda7de-0905-4cde-ba3f-717817be3ee6: Incorrect because the critical value or values we choose are based on the level of significance and the probability distribution associated with the test statistic.
answerFeedback.e6ed2c3a-3286-454e-9b35-8c2fef982aa8: Correct because the critical value or values we choose are based on the level of significance and the probability distribution associated with the test statistic.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.01-Quant-McDonald-12
entry.itemBody: If the prices of tech stocks usually rise when interest rates fall, the correlation between the two variables is most likely:

answerFeedback.3d074e07-da91-4a82-9ae6-4d1f8634c7e4: Correct because a negative correlation close to −1 indicates a strong negative (that is, inverse) linear relationship. The stem states that prices of tech stocks and interest rates move in opposite directions.
answerFeedback.777d13b0-c657-4444-ad1e-7be107154757: Incorrect because a positive correlation close to +1 indicates a strong positive linear relationship. The stem states that prices of tech stocks and interest rates move in opposite directions, not the same direction that would indicate a positive correlation.
answerFeedback.b6907305-dfdd-4c01-ac6e-483ce0235b9a: Incorrect because a correlation of 0 (uncorrelated variables) indicates an absence of any linear (that is, straight-line) relationship between the variables.

entry.title: ITEM_20170608309
entry.itemBody: Interest payable decreased during a company’s fiscal year. Compared with the amount of cash interest payments made, interest expense is most likely:

answerFeedback.310c7eb4-eea3-4f38-9be7-9c18fe1bfe9f: Incorrect. No change in interest payable would mean that interest expense equals cash paid for interest. In this case, interest payable has decreased.
answerFeedback.5553f406-4fe2-41db-b582-5c9fbd7426a2: Incorrect. An increase in interest payable would mean that interest expense is higher than cash paid for interest. In this case, interest payable has decreased.
answerFeedback.e5c1387d-cf97-4b97-b403-a21ac35d0d9f:
Correct. If the interest payable decreases during the year, then the interest expense on an accrual basis will be lower than the amount of cash interest payments. The cash paid would be the full amount of the expense plus the amounts paid to reduce the interest payable. For example,

Interest expense 100
Plus decrease in interest payable +12
Cash paid for interest 112

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-08029
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following year-end prices for a non-dividend-paying stock that was purchased at the end of Year 1 and sold at the end of Year 3:

Year Price
1 €6
2 €10
3 €12

Which of the following returns is the largest?

answerFeedback.83840431-4809-49ec-a979-b8d6c7aebe50: Incorrect because the arithmetic mean return is 43.34%, less than the two-year holding period return of 100%.
answerFeedback.8b7ec45c-7dcc-42b1-a603-49bf6c3c2f34: Incorrect because the geometric mean return is 41.42%, less than the two-year holding period return of 100%.
answerFeedback.d12cbb7e-e70e-4570-9c92-cb8ac1780400:
Correct because the two-year holding period return is the largest of the three returns.The annual HPRs over the first and second years are, respectively:

R1 = P1/P0 – 1 = €10/€6 – 1 = 66.67% and R2 = P2/P1 – 1 = €12/€10 – 1 = 20%.

Two-year HPR = P2/P0 – 1 = €12/€6 – 1 = 100%.

Geometric mean return RG = √[(1 + R1) × (1 + R2)] – 1 = √[(1 + 0.6667) × (1 + 0.2)] – 1 ≈ 41.42%.

Arithmetic mean return RA = (R1 + R2)/2 = (66.67% + 20%)/2 = 43.34%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-FRA-Lin-16
entry.itemBody: A company makes all sales on credit. According to the converged accounting standards for revenue recognition, a contract asset is most likely recognized on the seller's balance sheet when:

answerFeedback.7931d5d6-7e01-4ee2-b133-87e568ff305f: Incorrect because if the delivery was on credit, a related asset, such as trade or accounts receivable, is created. Later, when cash changes hands, the company’s financial records simply reflect that cash has been received to settle an account receivable.
answerFeedback.8e76f869-0048-4b78-be54-086a6376b6c8: Correct because when revenue is recognized, a contract asset is presented on the balance sheet. It is only at the point when all performance obligations have been met except for payment that a receivable appears on the seller’s balance sheet.
answerFeedback.ff30e198-4545-4a7e-a4be-3e52180a5e7d: Incorrect because a contract liability, instead of contract asset, should be recognized. If consideration is received in advance of transferring good(s) or service(s), the seller presents a contract liability.

choices.itemBody: A. goods or services are delivered and payment is received.
B. payment is received in advance of transferring the goods or services.
C. revenue is recognized related to some of the contractual performance obligations that have been met.

entry.title: ITEM_20180516093
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements relating to the financial reporting of defined contribution pension plans is correct?

answerFeedback.148f06ba-3ac4-4676-91ac-5d7087ae630c: Incorrect because, if some portion of the agreed-upon contribution has not been paid by fiscal year end, a liability is recognized on the balance sheet.
answerFeedback.20badacb-34c7-4af0-b955-0e0990cc5162: Incorrect because defined benefit plans (not defined-contribution plans) require companies to make several assumptions in order to estimate their pension obligations.
answerFeedback.57b0fba4-f0a4-48de-81d5-e0a0e22782b8: Correct. Under a defined-contribution plan, company contribution to the plan are treated as an operating cash flow.

choices.itemBody: A. The only balance sheet impact from contributions to defined-contribution plans is on an asset account
B. Under a defined-contribution plan, company contributions to the plan are treated as an operating cash flow
C. Defined-contribution plans require companies to make several assumptions in order to estimate their pension obligations

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-FRA-Lee-15
entry.itemBody: Line items can be expressed as a percentage of net revenue on which of the following common-size financial statements?

answerFeedback.247ce9bd-f563-428f-b4d2-a6b0ef897e38: Correct because in common-size analysis of a company’s income statement, each income and expense line item is expressed as a percentage of net revenues (net sales). For the common-size cash flow statement, there are two alternative approaches. The first approach is to express each line item of cash inflow (outflow) as a percentage of total inflows (outflows) of cash, and the second approach is to express each line item as a percentage of net revenue.
answerFeedback.71ef6d28-1e8e-49d7-9f08-513719d0fb9f: Incorrect because line items can be expressed as a percentage of net revenue in common-size analysis of both a company’s income statement and statement of cash flows.
answerFeedback.ae7e8645-c81c-4417-a599-22d1951b5fef: Incorrect because line items can be expressed as a percentage of net revenue in common-size analysis of both a company’s income statement and statement of cash flows.

choices.itemBody: B. The statement of cash flows only
C. Both the income statement and the statement of cash flows

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.01-Quant-Zhang-08
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following annual returns on a stock:

Year Return
1 5%
2 –2%
3 3%
4 8%

If the annual target return is 4%, the sample target semideviation of returns is closest to:

answerFeedback.82dfc489-6cc8-4fc2-8bb5-29da5be72e46: Incorrect because it wrongly uses n, not n – 1, as denominator in calculating the target semideviation. Hence, target semideviation = sqrt(0.0037/4) = 0.0304 ≈ 3.0%.
answerFeedback.c5baaabf-29b5-4e6e-8587-21fc29d908b0:
Correct because the target downside deviation, also referred to as the target semideviation, is a measure of dispersion of the observations (here, returns) below the target. The target semideviation, sTarget, is:
sTarget = sqrt[Σfor all Xi≤B n (Xi − B)2 / (n − 1)].

Calculation as below:

Year Observation Deviation from the 4% Target Deviations below the Target Squared Deviations below the Target
1 5% 1% — —
2 –2% –6% –6% 0.0036
3 3% –1% –1% 0.0001
4 8% 4% — —
Sum 0.0037

Hence, target semideviation = sqrt(0.0037/3) = 0.0351 ≈ 3.5%.
answerFeedback.de0950ed-9887-4e8a-9d43-76d2e8cd5bfc: Incorrect because it is the standard deviation, not the target semideviation. The mean is (5% +（–2%) + 3% + 8%)/4 = 3.5%. The standard deviation is sqrt{[(5% – 3.5%)2 + (–2% – 3.5%)2 + (3% – 3.5%)2 + (8% – 3.5%)2]/3} = sqrt(0.0053/3) = 0.0420 ≈ 4.2%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.08-CorpIssuers-Kashyap-01
entry.itemBody: A manufacturing company decides to invest in the maintenance of its IT hardware and software. This best describes a(n):

answerFeedback.09890b2e-38c0-436c-b5b0-5b0c25db935a: Incorrect because a company’s management will decide to invest in a unique activity outside, or only minimally related to, the company’s strategy. This happens more often with firms that are privately held or under the control of a founding owner or significant shareholder. Whether these projects are seen as special situations offering atypical growth or investment opportunities or innovation opportunities for the company’s business or business model, these projects are likely to be at the riskier end of capital investments.
answerFeedback.41c92e18-0c3f-4bdb-87e6-6836622a7fa6: Correct because going concern projects are those investments needed to continue the company’s current operations and maintain the existing size of the business. The most common going concern projects are replacements of assets that reach the end of their useful life and spending to maintain IT hardware and software.
answerFeedback.df8b1a79-4568-4357-ac6c-8e55505acbcd: Incorrect because expansion projects can be achieved by companies expanding the scale of existing activities or extending their reach into new product or service categories and markets. Expansion projects are those that increase business size, usually by investing in the development of new products or services and/or acquiring other companies.

entry.title: ITEM_20170608323
entry.itemBody:
A retailer that prepares its financial statements in accordance with IFRS has 100 office chairs in its inventory with a suggested retail price of $240 each, for which it paid a supplier an average of $200 a chair.

  • Demand for the chairs has been low for quite a while, and in response the supplier has lowered its selling price to $160 each.

  • However, the retailer estimates it can sell the chairs for $180 each if it offers free shipping to its customers. Shipping costs to the retailer are estimated to be $10 per chair, on average.

The total carrying amount of these 100 office chairs on the retailer’s balance sheet is closest to:

answerFeedback.ba84e137-cb88-4b9f-8dcd-df8f7804606f: Incorrect because costs (free shipping) to make a sale must be taken into consideration when determining net realizable value (not $180).
answerFeedback.dfbef8da-e3e7-4362-a5e8-87575c0bcaa4: Incorrect because this answer uses the $160 replacement cost.
answerFeedback.ff4e1aa4-cb3a-403d-b67c-22be73cad11c:
Correct because IFRS measures inventory at lower of cost and net realizable value. Net realizable value under IFRS is defined as the estimated selling price less the estimated costs necessary to get the inventory ready for sale and make the sale:

  • Selling price: $180

  • Costs to get ready to sell: $10 (Free shipping is required in order to sell these chairs at $180)

  • Net realizable value per chair: $170

  •  For 100 chairs: $17,000

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-FRA-Terry-11
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements is most accurate? The role of financial reporting is to:

answerFeedback.32abd9f7-ebf4-4ac1-92ed-a6debe339061: Correct because the role of financial statements issued by companies is to provide information about a company’s performance, financial position, and changes in financial position that is useful to a wide range of users in making economic decisions.
answerFeedback.8b005f90-291d-46fc-b0a4-a951756f13f6: Incorrect because this is a role of financial analysis. In evaluating financial reports, analysts typically have a specific economic decision in mind. Examples of these decisions can include forecasting future net income and cash flow.
answerFeedback.f2e62f76-9b41-429c-a6d6-d168e1a4381e: Incorrect because this is a role of financial analysis. In evaluating financial reports, analysts typically have a specific economic decision in mind. Examples of these decisions can include valuing a security for making an investment recommendation to others. Although financial reports do not show the value of an entity they are useful in estimating the value of an entity.

choices.itemBody: A. forecast future net income and cash flow.
B. value a security for making investment decisions.
C. provide information about a company's performance, financial position, and changes in financial position.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-01514
entry.itemBody: Which of the following financial statement disclosures regarding inventory are required under both IFRS and US GAAP?

answerFeedback.32baeea1-1a60-4518-a045-21f69eb4ebce: Incorrect because reversals of prior-year write-downs are not permitted under US GAAP, so the events leading to a reversal and the amount of the reversal are not applicable under US GAAP.
answerFeedback.a023a72b-112c-4869-ae5b-254fc55ecf11: Incorrect because reversals of prior-year write-downs are not permitted under US GAAP, so the events leading to a reversal and the amount of the reversal are not applicable under US GAAP.
answerFeedback.e4743a8b-8dd0-4aeb-af44-1bafbab9520b: Correct because both IFRS and US GAAP require disclosure of the amount of any write-down of inventories recognized as an expense during the period.

choices.itemBody: A. Events leading to a reversal of a write-down
B. The amount of any reversal of any write-down
C. The amount of any write-down recognized as an expense

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2023.06-CorpIssuers-Trent-02
entry.itemBody: The principal tool used to align the interests of management and shareholders is:

answerFeedback.68608bcf-23bb-4d94-a31b-d945adc2af96: Incorrect because in practice, compensation is the principal tool used to align the interests of management and shareholders.
answerFeedback.7131e905-38cf-4e91-9472-d2a2cb70df67: Incorrect because in practice, compensation is the principal tool used to align the interests of management and shareholders.
answerFeedback.75d82ce2-0de2-4da6-8d06-d9dfa132003d: Correct because in practice, compensation is the principal tool used to align the interests of management and shareholders.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Econ-Milosevic-01
entry.itemBody: The redistribution of income and wealth is most directly associated with:

answerFeedback.5cbaf61f-8841-491c-b18d-4db7fafefa1c: Correct because in addition, fiscal policy can be used to redistribute income and wealth.
answerFeedback.a2956baf-73b2-4209-9a8f-273ed1bb964c: Incorrect because the redistribution of income and wealth is associated with fiscal policy and not monetary policy. Instead, monetary policy refers to government or central bank activities that are directed toward influencing the quantity of money and credit in an economy.
answerFeedback.d6abbdf5-ad30-40d8-8206-ad59c154aa7b: Incorrect because the redistribution of income and wealth is associated with fiscal policy and not monetary policy. Instead, monetary policy refers to government or central bank activities that are directed toward influencing the quantity of money and credit in an economy.

choices.itemBody: C. both fiscal policy and monetary policy.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-FRA-Lin-03
entry.itemBody: Deductible temporary differences could arise when the:

answerFeedback.680a3e11-1a0e-41eb-913e-3ba62448e50c: Correct because deductible temporary differences result in a deferred tax asset when the tax base of an asset exceeds its carrying amount and, in the case of a liability, when the carrying amount of the liability exceeds its tax base. In addition, deferred tax assets, which appear on the balance sheet, arise when an excess amount is paid for income taxes (taxable income higher than accounting profit) and the company expects to recover the difference during the course of future operations.
answerFeedback.b84a81e0-e700-433c-aa87-e292f7bdab4c: Incorrect because it results in taxable temporary difference instead of deductible temporary difference. Taxable temporary differences result in a deferred tax liability when the carrying amount of an asset exceeds its tax base and, in the case of a liability, when the tax base of the liability exceeds its carrying amount.
answerFeedback.d777db86-761d-40a1-a8d4-6bc026e671d7: Incorrect because it results in a taxable temporary difference instead of deductible temporary difference. Taxable temporary differences result in a deferred tax liability when the carrying amount of an asset exceeds its tax base and, in the case of a liability, when the tax base of the liability exceeds its carrying amount. In addition, deferred tax liabilities, which also appear on the balance sheet, arise when a deficit amount is paid for income taxes and the company expects to eliminate the deficit over the course of future operations. In this case, financial accounting income tax expense exceeds income taxes payable.

choices.itemBody: B. carrying amount of an asset exceeds its tax base.
C. financial accounting income tax expense exceeds income taxes payable.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-Quant-Tsependa-04
entry.itemBody: Sampling error is the difference between the observed value of a statistic and the:

answerFeedback.4648bfb4-6448-4839-914c-7f709b7a2d93: Incorrect because sampling error is the difference between the observed value of a statistic and the quantity it is intended to estimate as a result of using subsets of the population, and not the observed value of the random variable.
answerFeedback.75ab17dc-4962-49c4-a529-2d197179c4b8: Correct because sampling error is the difference between the observed value of a statistic and the quantity it is intended to estimate as a result of using subsets of the population.
answerFeedback.ce83803e-1cbd-40a9-b8da-0a541ce72e36: Incorrect because sampling error is the difference between the observed value of a statistic and the quantity it is intended to estimate as a result of using subsets of the population, and not the mean of the sample.

choices.itemBody: B. quantity it is intended to estimate.
C. observed value of the random variable.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06249
entry.itemBody:
An analyst estimates the following risk premiums for a long-term corporate bond:

Inflation premium 1.5%
Default risk premium 2.0%
Liquidity premium 1.0%
Maturity premium 1.5%

If the short-term nominal risk-free interest rate is 4.0%, the yield on the bond is closest to:

answerFeedback.4f05e3bc-4757-4ab6-b202-bbc1b2a5f017: Incorrect because it is the sum of the nominal risk-free rate and the default risk premium and thus does not account for other risk premiums reflected in the interest rate; 4.0% + 2.0% = 6.0% (or 1.04 × 1.02 – 1 = 6.1% if multiplicative approach is used). It is also the sum of all given risk premiums: 1.5% + 2.0% + 1.0% + 1.5% = 6.0% (or 1.015 × 1.02 × 1.01 × 1.015 – 1 = 6.1% if multiplicative approach is used), which does not account for the real risk-free interest rate. Taking the perspective of investors in analyzing market-determined interest rates, we can view an interest rate r as being composed of a real risk-free interest rate plus a set of four premiums that are required returns or compensation for bearing distinct types of risk: r = Real risk-free interest rate + Inflation premium + Default risk premium + Liquidity premium + Maturity premium.
answerFeedback.a14ecfef-7906-4143-b248-921363b23c85: Incorrect because it double counts the inflation premium by using the nominal risk-free interest rate instead of the real risk-free interest rate, wrongly calculating r = 4.0% + 1.5% + 2.0% + 1.0% + 1.5% = 10% (or 1.04 × 1.015 × 1.02 × 1.01 × 1.015 – 1 = 10.4% if multiplicative approach is used). Taking the perspective of investors in analyzing market-determined interest rates, we can view an interest rate r as being composed of a real risk-free interest rate plus a set of four premiums that are required returns or compensation for bearing distinct types of risk: r = Real risk-free interest rate + Inflation premium + Default risk premium + Liquidity premium + Maturity premium, and the sum of the real risk-free interest rate and the inflation premium is the nominal risk-free interest rate.
answerFeedback.aab4eea0-528c-46fe-bd43-71060eac4a17: Correct because taking the perspective of investors in analyzing market-determined interest rates, we can view an interest rate r as being composed of a real risk-free interest rate plus a set of four premiums that are required returns or compensation for bearing distinct types of risk: r = Real risk-free interest rate + Inflation premium + Default risk premium + Liquidity premium + Maturity premium. Given that the sum of the real risk-free interest rate and the inflation premium is the nominal risk-free interest rate, the interest rate can be derived as r = Nominal risk-free interest rate + Default risk premium + Liquidity premium + Maturity premium = 4.0% + 2.0% + 1.0% + 1.5% = 8.5% (or 1.04 × 1.02 × 1.01 × 1.015 – 1 = 8.7% if multiplicative approach is used).

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-07852
entry.itemBody: An increase in which of the following will most likely allow governments to directly change income distribution?

answerFeedback.22cf4fe7-6a42-49c7-8873-de4fe151e2ec: Incorrect because infrastructure investment would assist an economy's growth, but the direct impact on income distribution would not be clear. Government spending on infrastructure is justified on the basis of economic and social grounds. For example, to provide such services as defense that benefit all citizens equally.
answerFeedback.a9ddfa09-7574-4025-aae7-7d7023b21764: Incorrect because with progressive income taxes rates households and corporations should pay proportionately more as their incomes rise. However, some people advocate ‘flat' tax rates, whereby all should pay the same proportion of taxable income. When a flat tax rate is applied to taxable income, the income distribution between high-income and low-income households does not change. For example, if the high-income household has 10 times as much taxable income as the low-income household, then the amount after tax for the high-income household is also 10 times as much.
answerFeedback.ce262aaf-8e7c-414d-88c4-7b45ca82b2b6: Correct because transfer payments exist to provide a basic minimum level of income for low-income households, and they also provide a means by which a government can change the overall income distribution in a society.

entry.title: ITEM_20170608119
entry.itemBody:
Because of significant changes in the marketplace, the demand for a company’s product has fallen and is not expected to recover to previous levels. The following information is related to the patent under which the product is produced:

Item Description $ thousands
Carrying value amount 36,000
Undiscounted expected future cash flows 38,000
Present value of expected future cash flows 32,000
Fair value if sold 34,000
Costs to sell 4,000


Which of the following statements is most accurate? The patent is impaired under:

answerFeedback.21307694-c875-45ad-9e45-e1f2924a01ca: Incorrect it is not impaired under US GAAP because the carrying value is greater than the undiscounted cash flows.
answerFeedback.ea425c01-54de-4a21-9b40-a374ea76d539: Incorrect because it is not impaired under US GAAP.
answerFeedback.eaf6bb37-6a0f-4fa6-adc0-871c904e5c2b:
Correct. Under IFRS (International Financial Reporting Standards), first determine the recoverable amount, which is the higher of:

  1. value in use (the present value of the expected future cash flows) = $32,000 or

  2. fair value minus costs to sell = $34,000 – 4,000 = $30,000

The recoverable amount ($32,000) is lower than the carrying value ($36,000). Therefore, the asset is impaired and should be written down to that amount.

Under US GAAP, to assess impairment, the carrying value ($36,000) is compared with the undiscounted expected future cash flows ($38,000). In this case, the carrying value is lower so the patent is not impaired.

entry.title: ITEM_20170531142
entry.itemBody: A liquidity trap is most closely associated with:

answerFeedback.6ca26684-89d3-4fcb-9082-88d382da7df0: Correct because a liquidity trap arises when the demand for money is infinitely elastic because individuals elect to hold additional money balances rather than respond to stimulative rate cuts by spending. As a result, weakening consumption leads to deflation.
answerFeedback.70b5035a-aa06-453a-a8f2-8f533a7b7eba: Incorrect because a liquidity trap is associated with an infinitely elastic (rather than inelastic) demand for money.
answerFeedback.715216d7-ca28-408c-b222-817b38db5cd2: Incorrect because a liquidity trap arises in the extreme instance under which the monetary authority has cut nominal interest rates to zero to stimulate the economy and cannot cut rates any further.

choices.itemBody: C. a positive nominal central bank policy rate.

entry.title: ITEM_20190530013
entry.itemBody: An exchange rate between two currencies has decreased to 1.3500. If the base currency has depreciated by 7% against the price currency, the initial exchange rate between the two currencies was closest to:

answerFeedback.1a6401db-6e2f-4570-a574-2e607b353123: Incorrect. The calculation incorrectly multiplies the current exchange rate by 1 plus the percentage depreciation in the exchange rate: 1.3500 × 1.07 = 1.4445.
answerFeedback.8749993f-78c1-4a7c-b19b-e43c4491bc77: Correct. To calculate the initial exchange rate, the current exchange rate is divided by 1 minus the percentage depreciation in the exchange rate of the base currency: 1.3500 ÷ (1 – 0.07) = 1.3500 ÷ 0.93 = 1.4516.
answerFeedback.eaaf57ea-996d-46e7-ba41-d2b4eaac00a7: Incorrect. The calculation incorrectly divides the current exchange rate by 1 plus the percentage depreciation in the exchange rate: 1.3500 ÷ 1.07 = 1.2617.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-CorpIssuers-Su-17
entry.itemBody: If interest is tax deductible, as the tax rate increases, the after-tax cost of debt for a company:

answerFeedback.88893d1a-bb3c-4afc-9a7e-9001632af1a0: Incorrect because referencing the equation rd(1 – t), if t increases, the after-tax cost of debt decreases, not increases. If interest can be deducted in full, the tax deductibility of debt reduces the effective marginal cost of debt to reflect the income shielded from taxation and the marginal cost of debt is rd(1 – t).
answerFeedback.8993c16d-1322-4b11-85b3-a2a6dacd7275: Correct because referencing the equation rd(1 – t), if t increases, the after-tax cost of debt decreases. If interest can be deducted in full, the tax deductibility of debt reduces the effective marginal cost of debt to reflect the income shielded from taxation and the marginal cost of debt is rd(1 – t).
answerFeedback.8f52bc67-4b64-45ea-a430-4498c1aa100a: Incorrect because referencing the equation rd(1 – t), if t increases, the after-tax cost of debt decreases, not remains the same. If interest can be deducted in full, the tax deductibility of debt reduces the effective marginal cost of debt to reflect the income shielded from taxation and the marginal cost of debt is rd(1 – t).

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-05265
entry.itemBody: Firms in monopolistic competition most likely have:

answerFeedback.16f352ee-77f4-479f-8d5b-de889284316b: Incorrect because only under perfect competition do firms have no pricing power. This is due to an absence of non-price competition combined with a standardized product, unlike monopolistic competition where firms have a differentiated product and can engage in non-price competition.
answerFeedback.5818cec0-7a61-418e-8a62-668fc1b75ca0: Correct because firms have some but not considerable pricing power under monopolistic competition. In this market structure, sellers are able to differentiate their products but at the same time can face a large number of competitors and low barriers to entry. The result is that firms have more pricing power than they would have under perfect competition (where there is no product differentiation) but less pricing power than in an oligopoly where entry barriers are high and there are fewer sellers.
answerFeedback.7cbb9bf1-8fe5-48cd-a1d1-0a11bd85a0e4: Incorrect because firms only have considerable pricing power in oligopolistic or monopoly market structures. Under monopolistic competition there are still many sellers due to low entry barriers, hence firms have some but not considerable pricing power.

entry.title: ITEM_20170608162
entry.itemBody: Amounts recorded as deferred revenue most likely become included in income when they are:

answerFeedback.1489d35d-d80c-427a-ac1e-38d4b94aa0bb: Incorrect because in situations in which a company is paid in advance for the delivery of a service or product in the future, it will recognize the cash received as an asset, but it also must recognize a liability for its obligation to deliver service or product in the future, typically referred to as deferred revenue. A deferred revenue liability account is derecognized upon the recognition of revenue when the entity satisfies its performance obligations.
answerFeedback.33d739ac-cdbb-4c97-84f9-ea495abec602: Correct because in situations in which a company is paid in advance for the delivery of a service or product in the future, it will recognize the cash received as an asset, but it also must recognize a liability for its obligation to deliver service or product in the future, typically referred to as deferred revenue. A deferred revenue liability account is derecognized upon the recognition of revenue when the entity satisfies its performance obligations.
answerFeedback.7318c65b-ae74-44df-9811-e42c32f55db3: Incorrect because in situations in which a company is paid in advance for the delivery of a service or product in the future, it will recognize the cash received as an asset, but it also must recognize a liability for its obligation to deliver service or product in the future, typically referred to as deferred revenue. A deferred revenue liability account is derecognized upon the recognition of revenue when the entity satisfies its performance obligations.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-Econ-Horvath-10
entry.itemBody: The role of lender of last resort in an economy is most likely fulfilled by the:

answerFeedback.1d0b7ee9-3a95-419b-937c-0dcef2ef53f4: Correct because most central banks act as the banker to the government and to other banks. They also act as a lender of last resort to banks. Because the central bank effectively has the capacity to print money, it is in the position to be able to supply the funds to banks that are facing a damaging shortage.
answerFeedback.910fbe40-b975-4fc8-9a2e-abf614b6ecfb: Incorrect because generally central banks are "the supervisor of the banking system" and act as the banker to the government and to other banks. They also act as a lender of last resort to banks. Because the central bank effectively has the capacity to print money, it is in the position to be able to supply the funds to banks that are facing a damaging shortage.
answerFeedback.bf7dee6e-65dd-4c0b-885d-3fcf02da6f32: Incorrect because most central banks act as the banker to the government and to other banks. They also act as a lender of last resort to banks. Because the central bank effectively has the capacity to print money, it is in the position to be able to supply the funds to banks that are facing a damaging shortage.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.01-CorpIssuers-Pitrakkou-02
entry.itemBody: Which of the following attributes is most accurate for a typical company in its start-up stage?

answerFeedback.3e664782-e7c1-4298-8d4f-4397f1fcbd77: Incorrect because early in its life, a company is typically a cash consumer. Investment is required to advance concepts through the prototype stage and into commercial production. Revenues are zero or minimal, and risk of business failure is high. The company must raise capital, and since the timing and potential for cash flow generation are highly uncertain, it will generally raise equity rather than debt. Equity for start-ups is usually sourced privately (e.g., through venture capital rather than in public markets through an IPO), in part because many stock exchange listing requirements include minimum profitability levels, which most start-ups have yet to achieve.
answerFeedback.80212ef0-0def-4d81-9445-d5cfbadf89c8: Incorrect because at this early stage, debt capital is typically not available or available only at a high cost. Additionally, debt is a negligible component of the capital structures of most start-up companies.
answerFeedback.fe83881b-198c-4fb0-945a-5a350814a112: Correct because at this early stage, debt capital is typically not available or available only at a high cost. Most lenders require stable and positive cash flow to service debt and/or collateral to secure it. An early-stage company often has neither, making it a high-risk prospect to lenders. With cash flows that are negative and unpredictable, a typical start-up would have difficulty making regular debt payments, or 'servicing the debt.'

choices.itemBody: B. The company can raise equity in public markets
C. Debt is a significant component of the capital structure

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.01-Quant-Tsependa-10
entry.itemBody: Monte Carlo simulations:

answerFeedback.111755ca-1980-4049-9afe-ade86ceee891: Incorrect because an important use of Monte Carlo simulation in investments is as a tool for valuing complex securities for which no analytic pricing formula is available.
answerFeedback.5703a101-e1a9-4580-bac0-466f7c3f6265: Correct because it is important to note that Monte Carlo simulation is a complement to analytical methods. It provides only statistical estimates, not exact results.
answerFeedback.9c03e170-46e8-40ee-82f9-7c78266f5875: Incorrect because analytical methods, where available, provide more insight into cause-and-effect relationships.

choices.itemBody: A. require analytical pricing formulas to value securities.
B. can be used as a complement to analytical methods.
C. provide better insight than analytical methods in cause-and-effect relationships.
